comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: This is Coney Island, but not Surf Avenue, which was (and is) much wider and had streetcar tracks. This is taken a block away, on Bowery, looking eastward, as this New York Historical Society photo from 1923 makes clear. digitalmetro.cdmhost.com/cdm/singleitem/collection/p16124... (the 'fit to window' button is the easiest way to see the picture) On the right of the NYHS photo, you see the metal stairs in the left foreground of LOC's photo, and the thing in the middle of the intersection.. a water fountain? Henderson's Music Hall was a Coney Island institution. In the LOC's photo, we see the electric sign at upper left with the top part of "Henderson's" cut off and the vaudeville acts listed below. Princess Radjah was a faux-Egyptian with a snake act based on Cleopatra's suicide by asp, only with a much bigger snake. The other acts were well known in their day on the Keith circuit, which ran Henderson's. You can also see the Brooklyn House on the other photo. Henderson's was demolished in 2010, the sad story here: amusingthezillion.com/2010/08/19/thors-coney-island-crack...
